questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: The viruses of the filoviridae family like Ebola and Marburg resemble which of the following morphologies? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3

 

  • Viruses belonging to the filoviridae family, such as Ebola and Marburg, resemble the morphology shown in image 3.
  • Image 3 - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Image 1- Influenza viruses have linear segmented, single-stranded RNA.

 

 

Image 2- Adenovirus is an icosahedroal symmetry with fibres extruding from vertices and contains double-stranded DNA.

 

 

Image 4 - Corona virus is non-segmented single-stranded RNA virus.

 

Coronavirus Structure

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Filoviruses, such as Ebola and Marburg, are filamentous and contain nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

choices.text: rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis
pLDH, Plasmodium malaria
Biopsy, Histoplasmosis
ELISA, HIV

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

 

This given clinical picture shows A and B. macrophage infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies (arrows) characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain) suggestive of Leishmaniasis which can be confirmed by the rk 39 antigen test.

 

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases: visceral (the most serious form because it is almost always fatal without treatment), cutaneous (the most common, usually causing skin ulcers), and mucocutaneous (affecting mouth, nose and throat).

 

Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

 

Following the discovery of a 39-amino acid residue (k-39) encoded by a kinesin-related gene in the amastigotes of Leishmania chagasi, it has been used in the format of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 

 

Immunochromatographic test (ICT) for detection of antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.1,4–6 Anti-k39 antibodies are secreted into various body fluids such as urine and sputum along with blood, and have been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (VL). rK39 strip test is rapid and a sensitive and specific indicator of visceral leishmaniasis(VL).

 

Parasitological methods of diagnosis remain the gold standard for diagnosing leishmaniasis. Diagnosis in the laboratory can be achieved by direct examination of amastigotes in giemsa-stained lesion smears of scrapping, biopsies, or impression smears.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. pLDH, Plasmodium malaria: Plasmodium malaria would present differently on a blood smear and would not typically show macrophages with intracellular organisms in a bone marrow sample. The pLDH test is specific for diagnosing malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Biopsy, Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis could cause fever of unknown origin and show organisms in macrophages, but the morphology would be different from Leishmania donovani. Histoplasma typically appears as small yeast forms within macrophages, not the double dot appearance seen here.

 

Option D. ELISA, HIV: While HIV can present with fever of unknown origin, it would not directly explain the bone marrow findings of intracellular Leishmania bodies. An ELISA test for HIV is not relevant to diagnosing the cause of the observed bone marrow pathology.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

questions.text: In the case of an elderly male presenting with meningitis, a gram stain of the CSF sample shows the presence of gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following statements accurately pertains to the motility of the responsible microorganism? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Motile at 25° C, non-motile at 37°C

 

  • The provided case involves an elderly man with meningitis, and the smear analysis indicates the presence of a gram-positive bacillus, strongly indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria exhibits motility at 25°C but loses its ability to move at 37°C.

 

LAB DIAGNOSIS OF LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES

 

  • Motility: shows differential motility, which is due to temperature dependent flagella expression) 
    • Tumbling type of motility at 25°C
    • Non-Motile at 37°C
  • Culture → Blood agar, Chocolate agar
  • Selective media → PALCAM agar

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Meningitis → DOC → Ampicillin in combination with gentamicin for synergistic effect
  • Penicillin allergy → Cotrimoxazole
  • In febrile gastroenteritis → Amoxicillin

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes exhibits motility at 25°C but is non-motile at 37°C.

questions.text: Match each disease with the correct causative agent from the options provided: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-2, b-3, c-4, d-1

 

The correct matching is:

 

  • Donovanosis - Klebsiella granulomatis (A-2)
  • Oroya fever - Bartonella bacilliformis (B-3)
  • Rat bite fever - Streptobacillus moniliformis (C-4)
  • Pinta - Treponema carateum (D-1)

 

For each disease:

 

  1. Donovanosis is a sexually transmitted infection that causes ulcerative lesions, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  2. Oroya fever, also known as Carrion's disease, is caused by Bartonella bacilliformis and is transmitted by sandflies.
  3. Rat bite fever is an infection caused by Streptobacillus moniliformis, typically transmitted through rat bites or contact with rat excreta.
  4. Pinta is a non-venereal treponematosis caused by Treponema carateum, characterized by skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The specific causative organisms for these bacterial diseases:

 

  • Donovanosis → Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Oroya fever → Bartonella bacilliformis
  • Rat bite fever → Streptobacillus moniliformis
  • Pinta → Treponema carateum

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with high-grade fever, and purpuric rash as shown in the image below. CS sample showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely aetiology? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The above image shows a purpuric rash seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci.

 

The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili.

 

From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteraemia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.

 

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and haemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages.

 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in immunocompromised hosts and those with chronic wounds but not typically presenting with purpuric rash and meningitis.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia: A common cause of bacterial meningitis but gram-positive and usually does not present with a purpuric rash.

 

Option D. E.coli: While it can cause meningitis in newborns and the elderly, it is not commonly associated with purpuric rash and gram-negative diplococci presentation in young adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a critical pathogen to consider in young adults presenting with symptoms of high-grade fever and a purpuric rash, especially when gram-negative diplococci are identified in the CSF. Rapid diagnosis and immediate treatment with appropriate antibiotics are crucial to prevent serious complications and mortality. This highlights the importance of vigilance for meningococcal disease in acute care settings.

questions.text: Match the following E. coli with their respective pathogenesis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

1. ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.
  • Match: A. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.

 

2. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Invades intestinal mucosal cells.
  • Match: B. Invades intestinal mucosal cells.

 

3. EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.
  • Match: C. Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.

 

4. EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.
  • Match: D. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a dematiaceous fungus

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.
  • The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • The aetiological agents gain entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds, usually by parts of plants.
  • In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e. sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.
  • The aetiological agent (i.e. fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.
  • Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Infection can spread and involve underlying subcutaneous tissue, tendon, muscle, or joints: This statement is more characteristic of eumycetoma, not chromoblastomycosis. Eumycetoma, caused by various fungal species, can invade deeper tissues including bone, leading to severe deformities.

 

Option C. Angioinvasion is common especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is typically seen in infections caused by Aspergillus species, which can lead to invasive aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This is not a feature of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by the engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: The bodies seen in the histological image (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophage engulfment. They are a morphological form of the fungi present in the infected tissue, indicative of chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by the presence of dark-coloured, thick-walled sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) in histological sections, resulting from traumatic implantation of dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI


The patient has symptomatic urinary symptoms, and the laboratory findings indicate the presence of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with a colony count greater than 10⁴. These characteristics point towards a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is known to be novobiocin-resistant and commonly implicated in UTIs, particularly in females. Since the patient is symptomatic, it is important to treat this condition as a UTI rather than dismissing or labeling it as contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take 3 consecutive urine samples: This option is incorrect because taking 3 consecutive urine samples is usually required for parasitic infections, where organisms are intermittently shed in the urine. For bacterial infections like this one, particularly with a significant growth of a specific organism, this is unnecessary.

 

Option B. No treatment required: This is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic. In symptomatic UTIs, especially with a significant colony count of a known pathogenic organism, treatment is essential. Leaving a symptomatic patient without treatment could lead to worsening of symptoms and complications.

 

Option C. It is a contaminated sample: This is incorrect because contamination is typically suggested when there are multiple types of organisms present or a mix of non-pathogenic flora. In this case, the growth of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus is specific and significant, aligning with clinical symptoms, ruling out contamination.

 

Educational Objective:


When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

questions.text: A female presented with a long history of fever, discolored skin of lower limbs, and lower limb edema. Microscopic examination showed a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial worm responsible for lymphatic filariasis, which often presents with symptoms such as prolonged fever, discolored skin, and limb edema due to lymphatic blockage. Microscopic examination of the organism reveals a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail, which is characteristic of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mansonella: Mansonella species are generally unsheathed microfilariae and do not match the description of having no nuclei at the tail tip, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Loa loa, also known as the African eye worm, is a sheathed microfilaria that has continuous nuclei to the very end of the tail, which distinguishes it from Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Option D. Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi is another sheathed filarial worm but is characterized by having nuclei at the tail tip, typically in two distinct spots, unlike Wuchereria bancrofti, which has none.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with symptoms of lymphatic filariasis and a sheathed microfilaria with no tail tip nuclei, Wuchereria bancrofti is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-3, b-1, c-4, d-2

 

A-3. Rotavirus is a member of the Reoviridae family, which is an exception among RNA viruses because it has double-stranded RNA (dsRNA).

 

B-1. SARS-CoV-2 is a coronavirus, which is a single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus.

 

C-4. Parvovirus is a unique DNA virus because it has single-stranded DNA (ssDNA).

 

D-2. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) belongs to the Papillomaviridae family and has double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the nucleic acid composition of viruses is crucial. Rotavirus has dsRNA, SARS-CoV-2 has ssRNA, Parvovirus has ssDNA, and HPV has dsDNA.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: Human herpesvirus 8 is associated with all except? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adult T-cell leukemia

 

Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by HTLV-1 (and not HHV8).

 

The Human Herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8), also called Kaposi sarcoma Herpesvirus (KSHV), belongs to the family of DNA viruses Herpeseviridae. It causes Kaposi sarcoma (a vascular malignancy) and B cell lymphoproliferative diseases such as primary effusion lymphoma (PEL) and multicentric Castleman disease (MCD).

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucor

 

Histopathological staining shows broad septate, hyaline hyphae with wide angle branching, which suggests that it is more likely Mucor.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus: Aspergillus shows aseptate narrow hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Talaromyces: Talaromyces is a genus of fungi that forms septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Option D. Blastomyces: Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus that appears as broad-based budding yeast in tissue sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is identified by broad aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide-angle branching, and it typically lacks rhizoids, unlike Rhizopus which has nodal rhizoids.

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

 

CB-NAAT and Line probe assay are rapid molecular diagnostic techniques used for diagnosis of tuberculosis and also to assess resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin.

 

CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance. It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites.

 

It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB in key populations such as pediatric population, PLHIV and extrapulmonary TB.

 

It is done when smear is negative for TB but chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in cases smear is negative and chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is high index of clinical suspicion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Line probe assay: Line probe assay is another molecular diagnostic test used for detecting resistance to first-line and second-line anti-TB drugs. However, it is not the first choice for initial diagnosis following a negative sputum smear but suggestive chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Liquid culture: Liquid culture is used for confirming TB diagnosis and drug susceptibility testing. It is more time-consuming compared to molecular tests like CBNAAT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is a common viral illness caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The disease typically affects young children. It is characterized by a high fever lasting for three to five days, which abruptly resolves and is followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash consists of small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. It is typically nonpruritic, blanching, and can persist from one to two days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

In contrast, petechial rashes are small, pinpoint, red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin and are associated with the following diseases:

 

Option A. Zika Virus: Zika virus infection can cause a mild, dengue-like illness, which includes symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. The rash can be maculopapular, and in some cases, petechiae can be observed.

 

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease: This is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India. It is caused by the Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV) and presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle pain, vomiting, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hemorrhagic manifestations, including petechiae.

 

 

Option D. West Nile Fever: This disease is caused by the West Nile virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, including fever, headache, body aches, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, neurological complications. Petechial rashes can occur in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Vaccine can be prepared against which of the following proteins of the virus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

The L1 protein of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a major capsid protein and is the primary antigen used in the development of HPV vaccines. L1 proteins can self-assemble into virus-like particles (VLPs) which mimic the natural virus structure but do not contain viral DNA, making them non-infectious. These VLPs elicit a strong immune response, providing protection against HPV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6 and E7 proteins: These are oncogenes of HPV responsible for cellular transformation and promoting oncogenesis. These proteins drive cell cycle allowing genome amplification in upper epithelial layers and degrade tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and pRb. They are not used for vaccine preparation as they do not induce a protective immune response.

 

Option C. E1 and E2 proteins: These are involved in viral replication and transcription regulation. E1 acts as an origin binding protein and ATPase-dependent helicase, while E2 regulates viral gene transcription and is associated with E1 for viral genome partitioning. They are not targets for the current vaccines.

 

Option D. DE3: This option is not relevant to HPV proteins in the context of vaccine development.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

 

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophila, previously known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
  • It displays susceptibility to cotrimoxazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proteus mirabilis:

 

  • Resistant to: Nitrofurantoin, Tetracyclines
  • Susceptible to aminoglycosides, carbapenems, cephalosporins, cotromoxazole, penicillin+ β-lactamase inhibitors.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, especially in cystic fibrosis patients, and opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

 

  • Known for resistance to multiple antibiotics, but typically not specifically resistant to meropenem.
  • Susceptible to: A wide range of antibiotics, often including aminoglycosides, depending on the strain.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, wound infections, and urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Acinetobacter baumannii:

 

  • Known for multi-drug resistance, including to carbapenems like meropenem.
  • Susceptibility varies, but generally not as consistently susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate as Stenotrophomonas maltophila.
  • Clinical manifestations: Hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and bloodstream infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organisms shown below acts via? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ADP ribosylation of EF2

 

The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and a Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

 

Diphtheria toxin functions by selectively ADP-ribosylating ribosomal elongation factor, EF-2, attenuating protein synthesis and leading to cell death within a matter of hours. DT is a highly potent toxin. It is bacteriophage mediated.

 

NOTE: Pseudomonas toxin also inhibits protein synthesis by ADP ribosylation of EF2.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increase in cAMP: This mechanism is typically associated with toxins such as cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which lead to an increase in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) by ADP-ribosylating G proteins, but not involved in the action of diphtheria toxin.

 

Option B. Increase in cGMP: This mechanism is not relevant to diphtheria toxin but is associated with certain bacterial toxins like heat-stable enterotoxin (ST) produced by E. coli, which increases cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels.

 

Option D. RNA glycosidase: This mechanism refers to Shiga toxin and ricin, which inhibit protein synthesis by enzymatically removing adenine from rRNA, but it is not the mode of action for diphtheria toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), thereby inhibiting protein synthesis and leading to cell death.

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia

 

 

The patient's condition suggests a subcutaneous infection that has progressed to involve deeper tissues, leading to a discharging ulcer. The key diagnostic clue here is the microscopic finding of gram-positive filamentous rods with branching, which is characteristic of Nocardia. Nocardia is a type of actinomycete, a group of gram-positive bacteria known for their branching filamentous structure. This presentation is consistent with actinomycetoma, a type of mycetoma caused by bacteria, as opposed to eumycetoma, which is caused by fungi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Candida is a yeast, not a gram-positive filamentous rod. It typically presents as budding yeasts and pseudohyphae rather than branching rods, making it an incorrect option for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which presents with ulcerative lesions along lymphatic channels. It does not appear as gram-positive filamentous rods, making it inconsistent with the given microscopic findings.

 

Option C. Histoplasma: Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus that appears as intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. It does not have the filamentous, branching rod structure observed in this case, eliminating it as a possible answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

 

The patient with given complaints points to meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae and it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus colonies. When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus.

 

H. influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided

 

When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, then factor V is released from S. aureus.

 

It forms larger colonies adjacent to S. aureus streak line and size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line, this is known as Satellitism. Therefore, used for the isolation of H. influenzae.

 

 

 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

 

  1. Factor X = hemin→ present freely in blood
  2. Factor V = Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) →present inside RBCs (also produced by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus)

 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and less commonly suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis.

 

DOC - Cefotaxime or ceftazidime

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bacitracin sensitive: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram positive coccus.

 

Option B. Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar: Associated with organisms such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Proteus species.

 

Option D. It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar: Alpha-hemolysis on blood agar is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumonia, a gram-positive coccus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Haemophilus influenzae infection, particularly meningitis, look for satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, indicating the organism's dependence on externally sourced V factor for growth.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella/ Salmonella.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

  • Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
  • Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.
  • Alkaline peptone water (Option-B) - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of anaerobic bacteria, not typically involved in cases of dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This is used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases suspected of cholera, which typically presents with watery diarrhea rather than bloody stools.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: It is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus, it is a yeast like organism that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Dimorphic fungi are fungi that can exist in two different forms depending on the temperature.
  • At 25°C (room temperature), they grow in a mold (mycelial) form.
  • At 37°C (body temperature), they grow in a yeast form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomyces dermatitidis: A dimorphic fungus causing blastomycosis.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: A dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis.

 

Option D. Penicillium marneffei: A dimorphic fungus causing penicilliosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii is not a dimorphic fungus

 

Dimorphic fungi:

 

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicillium marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Coccidioides posadasii

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Botulinum

 

The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

 

Clostridium botulinum is non-invasive. Its pathogenesis is due to the production of powerful neurotoxin ‘botulinum toxin’ (BoNT). It produces flaccid paralysis. There are 7 serological types of botulinum neurotoxin labeled as types A, B, C [C1 C2], D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is caused mainly by types A, B, E and F (rarely).

 

After entry (either ingested, inhaled, or produced in a wound), botulinum toxin is transported via the blood to peripheral cholinergic nerve terminals. The most common nerve terminal sites are neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia. It does not affect the CNS.

 

Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins that are required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles, thereby preventing the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the peripheral nerve endings, including neuromuscular junctions (presynaptic inhibition). This results in a lack of stimulus to the muscle fibers, irreversible relaxation of the muscles to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal, and flaccid paralysis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tetanus: Tetanus toxin (produced by Clostridium tetani) acts by inhibiting neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system by cleaving synaptobrevin, another SNARE protein, but it causes spastic paralysis rather than flaccid paralysis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin (produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae) inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is a completely different mechanism from that of botulinum toxin.

 

Option D. Pertussis: Pertussis toxin (produced by Bordetella pertussis) modifies the signaling of G-protein coupled receptors by ADP-ribosylating the Gi protein, thereby affecting cellular communication but not directly impacting acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at peripheral nerve endings through the proteolysis of SNARE proteins necessary for acetylcholine vesicle exocytosis.

questions.text: Match the following in the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

The image depicts the life cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which involves various hosts and vectors. Here's the correct matching:

 

  1. Accidental host (Human) - c: Humans are considered accidental hosts for JEV as they do not contribute to the ongoing transmission cycle.
  2. Amplifier (Pigs) - d: Pigs serve as amplifier hosts where the virus replicates to high levels, increasing the likelihood of mosquito transmission.
  3. Reservoir (Ardeid bird) - a: Birds, particularly Ardeid birds (herons and egrets), act as natural reservoirs of JEV.
  4. Vector (Culex) - b: Culex mosquitoes are the primary vectors that transmit JEV from reservoir hosts to amplifier hosts and to accidental hosts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle:

 

  • Humans are accidental hosts.
  • Pigs are amplifier hosts.
  • Ardeid birds are reservoir hosts.
  • Culex mosquitoes are the vectors responsible for transmission.

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

questions.text: Which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba

 

Stools with mucus and abdominal pain are seen in infection due to Entamoeba.

 

Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:

 

  • Dysentery accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence. Stools usually have blood and mucus.
  • Chronic amebiasis presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
  • A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giardia: Is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence. BUT does not release mucus in stool.

 

Option C. Campylobacter: Presents with fever, pain and watery diarrhea. Stool contains leucocytes and blood.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcal food poisoning is toxin-mediated and presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica infection presents with dysentery, characterized by stools containing mucus and blood, along with abdominal pain.

questions.text: What is the microscopy technique to produce high contrast image of transparent, live bacteria? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phase contrast microscopy

 

Phase-contrast microscopy (PCM) is an optical microscopy technique that converts phase shifts in light passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image. Phase shifts themselves are invisible, but become visible when shown as brightness variations.

 

Contrast is improved by using the difference in thickness or refractive index of structures within and around the cell. Difference in intensity of light is created as rays pass through varied refractive indices and produces contrast thus making the structures within the cells and its surroundings clearly visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Option C. The electron microscope uses a beam of electrons and their wave-like characteristics to magnify an object's image, unlike the optical microscope that uses visible light to magnify images.

 

Option D. Polarized microscopy is used to visualize the intracellular structures using differences in birefringence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to produce high contrast images of transparent, live bacteria by converting phase shifts into brightness changes.

choices.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA
Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

 

Southern Blotting: This technique is used for the detection of specific DNA sequences in DNA samples. This is not applicable for detecting SARS-CoV-2 because the virus is RNA-based and there is not enough DNA in the collected samples to obtain a pattern on gel electrophoresis. RNA viruses require different techniques such as RT-PCR for detection.

 

Other Options

 

Tests for SARS CoV2

 

  • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR):

  • Method: This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.

  • Explanation: It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.

  • Rapid Antigen Test:

  • Method: This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.

  • Explanation: It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.

  • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay):

  • Method: This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.

  • Explanation: It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.

 

Educational Objective

 

Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

choices.text: Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding scrub typhus except: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

 

Causative organism – Orientia tsutsugamushi (an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium).

 

They cannot grow on cell free media. They are readily cultivated in yolk sac of developing chick embryos. They also grow on mouse fibroblast, HeLa, Hep-2, Detroit 6 and other continuous cell lines.

 

Vector - Infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus. Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Signs and Symptoms- Fever and chills, Headache, Body aches and muscle pain. Dark, scab-like region at the site of the chigger bite (also known as eschar). Mental changes, ranging from confusion to coma. Enlarged lymph nodes and rash are also seen.

 

Diagnosis of scrub typhus that includes enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), immunofluorescence assay (IFA), immunochromatographic test (ICT), Weil–Felix, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmitted by chiggers: This is true. Scrub typhus is transmitted by the larvae (chiggers) of trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Lymphadenopathy is a feature: This is true. Enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) are a common feature of scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Man is an accidental host: This is true. Humans are accidental hosts who become infected when they come into contact with infected chiggers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that cannot grow on cell-free media like MacConkey agar. It requires living cells for its cultivation. Scrub typhus is transmitted by chiggers and features symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite. Humans are accidental hosts for this infection.

choices.text: Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction
A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent
FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

questions.text: A patient presents to you with left-sided flank pain. A CT scan was done which is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) FNAC or biopsy to be done before nephrectomy

 

Above CT image shows left renal hydatid cyst. In this case, FNAC or biopsy should not be done before nephrectomy as puncture of the cyst while obtaining cystic fluid may cause escape of hydatid fluid and consequent anaphylaxis. Therefore, fluid aspirated from surgically removed cyst should only be examined.

 

Echinococcus causes hydatid cyst in man. It is segmented and smaller than other cestodes.

 

Most of the times infection is asymptomatic and accidentally discovered.

 

Clinical disease develops only when the hydatid cyst has grown big enough to cause obstructive symptoms. Disease results mainly from pressure effects caused by the enlarging cysts.

 

In about half the cases, the primary hydatid cyst occurs in liver, mostly in the right lobe. Hepatomegaly, pain and obstructive jaundice are the usual manifestations.

 

The next common site is the lung (25%) (most common being the lower lobe of the right lung). Cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, pneumothorax and dyspnea constitute the clinical picture.

 

In the kidney (2%), hydatid cyst causes pain and hematuria.

 

Apart from pressure effects, another pathogenic mechanism in hydatid disease is hypersensitivity to the echinococcal antigen. The host is sensitized to the antigen by minute amounts of hydatid fluid seeping through the capsule. Hypersensitivity may cause urticaria. But if a hydatid cyst ruptures spontaneously or during surgical interference/FNAC, massive release of hydatid fluid may cause severe, even fatal anaphylaxis.

 

CT imaging is diagnostic to visualize daughter cysts within large cysts

 

Treatment

 

Traditionally surgical removal was considered as the best mode of treatment of cysts.

 

Currently, ultrasound staging is recommended and management depends on the stage.

 

In early stages, the treatment of choice is puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration (PAIR).

 

Puncture, aspiration, injection and reaspiration, considered as a controversial procedure earlier, is now widely used in early stages of the disease. The basic steps involved in PAlR include:

 

  • Ultrasound or CT-guided puncture of the cyst.
  • Aspiration of cyst fluid.
  • Infusion of sporicidal agent (usually 95% ethanol; alternatively, hypertonic saline)
  • Reaspiration of the fluid after 5 minutes.
  • Great care is taken to avoid spillage and cavities are sterilized with 0.5% silver nitrate or 2.7% sodium chloride for prophylaxis of secondary peritoneal echinococcosis due to inadvertent spillage of fluid du ring PAIR.

 

Albendazole (15 mg/ kg in row divided doses) is initiated 4 days before the procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards.

 

Surgery: It is the treatment of choice for complicated E. granulosus cysts like those communicating with the biliary tract and in those cysts where PAIR is not possible.

 

Renal involvement requires surgical treatment, either simple excision of the cyst or partial/total nephrectomy if extensive disease.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Albendazole can be started preoperatively: This is correct. Albendazole (15 mg/kg in two divided doses) is initiated 4 days before any surgical or puncture procedure and continued for 4 weeks afterwards to reduce the risk of spillage and subsequent anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option B. Cyst contents can produce anaphylactic reaction: This is correct. The contents of a hydatid cyst contain highly antigenic material, and rupture or spillage of this material can cause a severe anaphylactic reaction.

 

Option C. A segmented dog tapeworm is the causative agent: This is correct. Echinococcus granulosus, a segmented tapeworm found in dogs, is the causative agent of hydatid disease.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is characterized by cyst formation in organs such as the liver, lungs, and kidneys. FNAC or biopsy should not be done in cases of suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis and dissemination of the infection.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: Associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.

 

List of Oncogenic Microbe:

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a widespread disease caused by a tick-borne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family. The CCHF virus causes severe viral haemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10–40%.

 

CCHF is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East and Asian countries south of the 50th parallel north – the geographical limit of the principal tick vector. Outbreak in Gujarat, India occurred in 2011.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow fever is mostly endemic to the south and central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Option C. Ebola virus is located mainly in sub-Saharan Africa

 

Option D. Hendra virus mainly confined to north-eastern coast of Australia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported to have endemic transmission in India, specifically with an outbreak in Gujarat in 2011.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mature dendritic cells

 

Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells as they possess higher levels of MHC-II. They also have costimulatory membrane proteins which are required for activation of T cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.

 

 

Option C. B lymphocytes: While B cells can act as antigen-presenting cells, they are not as effective as dendritic cells in stimulating naive T cells. They typically present antigens to already activated T cells rather than naive ones.

 

Option D. NK cell: Natural killer (NK) cells are involved in the innate immune response and do not function as antigen-presenting cells. They are responsible for recognizing and killing virally infected cells and tumor cells without the need for antigen presentation.

 

Educational Objective:


Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulators of naive T cells due to their high levels of MHC-II and costimulatory molecules.

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with painful vesicles as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus

 

The condition shown in the image is characterized by painful vesicles, which is a hallmark of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. HSV causes fluid-filled vesicles that are often painful, and these lesions can occur on the skin or mucous membranes, including genital areas. The vesicles eventually rupture, forming shallow, painful ulcers. HSV can present as recurrent outbreaks, especially during periods of stress or weakened immune function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Candidiasis typically presents with white, curd-like discharge and redness, particularly in mucous membranes like the mouth or vagina. It does not cause vesicles or painful ulcers.

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless chancre in the primary stage, followed by a rash and other systemic symptoms in later stages. Vesicles are not a feature of syphilis.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents with painful genital ulcers but does not form fluid-filled vesicles. The ulcers are more ragged and deeper compared to those seen in HSV infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful vesicles are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. Remember the association of HSV with painful, fluid-filled vesicles, especially in genital or mucosal areas.

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum


The LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount in the image shows structures with a tuberculate appearance, which are characteristic of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in certain areas of the United States, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. The tuberculate macroconidia seen on LPCB mounts are a diagnostic feature of Histoplasma, and this form helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis typically presents with spherules containing endospores in tissue, not the tuberculate structures seen in this LPCB mount. Coccidioides is known for causing coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), primarily seen in arid regions like the southwestern US.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis shows a broad-based budding yeast form in tissues, and does not present with tuberculate structures. A classic LPCB mount of Blastomyces would show the figure-of-eight appearance of budding yeast cells, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis
Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris

questions.text: A woman with recurrent diarrhea is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Which of the following is not true regarding Clostridium difficile infection?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

 

  • IgM assay cannot be used to confirm a diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin in stool samples.
  • C. difficile, a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus, causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection (CDI) after ingestion of spores of the organism.
  • The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). It is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin.
  • The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.
  • The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins - toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation.
  • The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.
  • Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin  A Or Toxin B or the organism in stool samples. The mere presence of bacteria in stool does not itend that the patient has the disease as clostridoides difficile is a commensal in the gut. Onlly confirmed toxin detection suggests significant infection with clostridoides difficile  This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 
  • Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment: This is true; fidaxomicin is a first-line treatment for C. difficile infection, especially in cases of recurrence.

 

Option B. It is toxin mediated: True; the clinical manifestations of CDI are due to the effects of toxins A and B.

 

Option D. Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris: Also true, this describes the characteristic appearance of the pseudomembrane seen in pseudomembranous colitis, a severe form of CDI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile infection is diagnosed primarily through the detection of toxins rather than IgM assays is crucial for appropriate management. This recognition guides the effective use of specific treatments such as oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin, aimed at countering the effects of these toxins and managing the symptoms of the infection.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below, which causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EPEC

 

Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

 

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 

Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

 

  • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETEC: ETEC is known for causing watery diarrhea via enterotoxins but does not cause the attachment and effacement lesions seen with EPEC.

 

Option B. EIEC: EIEC causes invasive disease and dysentery by invading and destroying epithelial cells, but it does not cause attachment and effacement lesions.

 

Option D. EHEC: EHEC causes hemorrhagic colitis and can lead to hemolytic-uremic syndrome through the production of Shiga toxin, but it does not cause the effacement and attachment of intestinal cells as EPEC does.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A person who has undergone a bone marrow transplant in the past is now presenting with a lung lesion. Upon microscopic analysis, the image of the lesion is provided below. What is the probable responsible organism for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mucormycosis

 

Explanation:

 

Mucormycosis is indicated in this clinical scenario due to the patient's history of a bone marrow transplant and the presence of a lung lesion. The image provided shows broad aseptate hyphae , which is characteristic of Mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma: Is a dimorphic fungus. At 25°C, it shows mycelial phase and at 37°C, it shows Yeast form.

 

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: Colonies can be demonstrated by negative staining of their capsule.

 

 

Option D. Aspergillosis: Shows narrow, acute angled branching and septate, differing from the non-septate hyphae

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis  is characterized broad aseptate hyphae with acute -angle branching. which commonly affecting in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Which of the following components of the fungal cell wall is not seen in mucormycosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta 1, 3, glucan

 

An abundant cell wall polysaccharide, (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) is found in most fungi, with the notable exception of the cryptococci, the zygomycetes (mucor and Rhizopus), and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.

 

Fungal cell wall:

 

  • Fungal cell walls are rigid and contain complex polysaccharides called chitin (adds structural strength) and glucans.
  • Ergosterol is the steroid molecule in the cell membranes that replaces the cholesterol found in animal cell membranes.

 

Clinical significance of Beta-1, 3-d-glucan:

 

G-test: Detects a-3 glucan. Used in diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Tests for beta-d-glucan: Raised levels are seen in candidiasis, aspergillosis, and pneumonia due to Pneumocystis carnii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannoproteins: Mannoproteins are glycoproteins found in the fungal cell wall, contributing to its structure and function.

 

Option C. Chitin: Chitin is a structural polysaccharide found in the cell walls of fungi, including those causing mucormycosis. It provides rigidity and strength to the cell wall.

 

Option D. Ergosterol: Ergosterol is a component of fungal cell membranes, not the cell wall. It replaces cholesterol found in animal cell membranes and is essential for maintaining membrane integrity and function in fungi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta 1, 3, glucan is absent or minimally present in the cell walls of fungi causing mucormycosis, distinguishing them from many other fungi that have this polysaccharide as a major cell wall component. This characteristic is significant in the diagnosis and treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: A patient presented with meningitis with a history of fever for 4 days and erythematous rashes on the chest. There was no history of travel and tick bite. His CSF findings showed increased protein, normal glucose, mild lymphocytosis and few RBCs. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this clinical picture? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterovirus

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings are suggestive of viral meningitis, most probably caused by an Enterovirus. Enteroviruses are common causes of viral meningitis and present with fever, rashes, and mild lymphocytosis in the CSF.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. West Nile virus: Although it can cause meningitis, there is no history of travel, making this less likely. West Nile virus is endemic in certain regions of North America like California Central Valley, southwestern Arizona, southern Texas, and Louisiana, which have both compatible climates and avian reservoirs for the disease.

 

Option B. Meningococci: Typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Option C. Strep pneumoniae: Also typically causes bacterial meningitis with higher neutrophil count and lower glucose levels in the CSF.

 

Educational objective

 

CSF Findings for Different Types of Meningitis:

questions.text: The disruption of which of the following is responsible for watery diarrhea in cholera caused by Vibrio? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zonula occludens
