When cholera toxin is released from the bacteria in the infected intestine, it binds to the intestinal cells known as enterocytes through the interaction of the pentameric B subunit of the toxin with the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the intestinal cell, triggering endocytosis of the toxin.

 

Next, the A/B cholera toxin must undergo cleavage of the A1 domain from the A2 domain in order for A1 to become an active enzyme.

 

Once inside the enterocyte, the enzymatic A1 fragment of the toxin A subunit enters the cytosol, where it activates the G protein Gsa through an ADP-ribosylation reaction that acts to lock the G protein in its GTP-bound form, thereby continually stimulating adenylate cyclase to produce cAMP. 

 

The high cAMP levels activate the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), causing a dramatic efflux of ions and water from infected enterocytes, leading to watery diarrhea.

 

 

The effects of cholera involve the actions of other Vibrio cholerae toxins that aid the pathogen in its colonization, coordinated expression of virulence factors, and toxin action.

 

These additional proteins include

 

  • Zona occludens toxin (zot, involved in Vibrio cholerae invasion by acting to decrease intestinal tissue resistance)
  • Accessory cholera toxin (ace, increases fluid secretion)
  • Toxin-coregulated pilus (tcpA, essential colonisation factor receptor for the CTXf phage)
  • NAG-specific heat-labile toxin (st)
  • Outer membrane porin proteins (ompU and ompT).
  • The expression of virulence factors is controlled by the transcriptional factors ToxR, TcpP and ToxT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intercalated discs: Found in cardiac muscle cells and involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and electrical coupling, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option B. Macula densa: Involved in regulating kidney function and blood pressure, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Option D. Hemidesmosomes: Involved in cell-to-extracellular matrix adhesion, not related to intestinal fluid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disruption of zonula occludens (tight junctions) by cholera toxin is responsible for the increased permeability of intestinal epithelial cells, leading to the characteristic watery diarrhea seen in cholera.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss and looked jaundiced. Upon further investigation, you suspect a parasitic infection. You obtain a stool sample and operculated eggs in the feces. Further examination reveals the presence of a parasite with a complex life cycle with snail and plants as the intermediate host. Which parasite is most likely responsible for the above symptoms? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica

 

Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals.

 

Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

 

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation.

 

Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.

 

Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fasciolopsis buski: Fasciolopsis buski is an intestinal fluke, and while it also involves snails as intermediate hosts, it does not primarily target the liver. Infection typically occurs through ingestion of aquatic plants, but the symptoms and life cycle do not match those described.

 

Option C. Paragonimus westermani: Paragonimus westermani, the lung fluke, has a complex life cycle involving snails and crustaceans. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms rather than abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Eggs are typically found in sputum, not feces.

 

Option D. Clonorchis sinensis: Clonorchis sinensis, the Chinese liver fluke, also involves snails as intermediate hosts and can cause liver-related symptoms. However, the life cycle and specific hosts differ slightly from Fasciola hepatica. It primarily affects the liver and bile ducts but is more common in certain geographic regions.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Fasciola hepatica, the sheep liver fluke, is diagnosed by identifying eggs in the feces, and it has a complex life cycle involving snails and aquatic vegetation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness that presents as a vesicular eruption in the mouth, but it can also involve the hands, feet, buttocks, and/or genitalia. Caused by Coxsackie A virus. The presence of vesicular rashes in these specific locations is a hallmark of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In Dengue Fever, the initial rash is a transient flushing erythema of face that typically occurs shortly before or within the first 24-48 hours of the onset of symptoms and is thought to be the result of capillary dilatation. The second rash usually occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and it is characterized by asymptomatic maculopapular or morbilliform eruption.

 

Option C. The rash associated with the Zika virus is a combination of flat blotches (macules) and raised tiny reddish bumps like papules (not as petechiae)

 

Option D. In roseola infantum, upon rapid defervescence of the fever around days three to five, small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules will develop. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. The rash is typically nonpruritic, blanching and can persist from one to two days. Caused by HHV 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicular rash is specifically seen in Hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD21

 

  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor on the cell surface. CD21, also known as complement receptor 2 (CR2), is a receptor for the C3d fragment of the complement system and serves as the entry point for EBV into B cells. This interaction facilitates the virus's ability to infect and establish latency within B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD20: This is a protein expressed on the surface of all B cells and is involved in B cell activation and proliferation. It is not used by EBV for cell entry.

 

Option C. CD19: This is a surface protein that acts as a co-receptor in B cell receptor signaling, but it is not directly involved in EBV entry.

 

Option D. CD23: This is the low-affinity receptor for IgE and does not play a role in EBV infection of B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered to be the best for the detection of Clostridium difficile? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay

 

A combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assay can be used for the detection of Clostridium difficile.

 

Clostridium difficile is a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus that causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection after ingestion of spores of the organism. The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). Enzyme immunoassay to detect glutamate dehydrogenase is less specific compared to toxin detection for diagnosis. So a combination of the two can be used for diagnostic confirmation.

 

The condition is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use, which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin. The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.

 

The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins-toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation. The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plagues initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.

 

Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin or the organism in stool samples. This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PC) or by culture.

 

Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and adequate hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aerobic culture of stool: C. difficile is an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture inappropriate and ineffective for its cultivation.

 

Option C. Glutamate dehydrogenase assay alone: While sensitive, it lacks specificity for the detection of toxin-producing strains.

 

Option D. None of the above: There are effective methods, particularly the one described in option B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective and accurate diagnosis of Clostridioides difficile infection, a combination of glutamate dehydrogenase and toxin assays is recommended. This approach ensures both the presence of the organism and its potential to cause disease through toxin production are assessed, guiding appropriate treatment and infection control measures.

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toluidine and malachite green

 

Albert stain is used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria, such as those seen in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The staining technique involves two solutions: Albert stain 1 and Albert stain 2. Albert stain 1 contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, which are basic dyes with a high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. Toluidine blue stains the granules blue, while Malachite green provides a green background. This differential staining helps in visualizing the metachromatic granules distinctly.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect as Carbol fuschin is used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining for acid-fast bacteria, and methylene blue is a counterstain in that procedure.

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is incorrect because Carbol fuschin is not used in Albert staining; it is used in acid-fast staining procedures.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect for Albert staining. Methylene blue is a basic dye used in various other staining techniques, but not in Albert stain.

 

Educational Objective:


Albert stain contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A person arrived with a lesion on their left buttock. This individual has a past medical record of undergoing a heart transplant 15 years ago. Analysis of the fluid extracted from the lesion reveals the presence of gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the probable microbial agent responsible for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia

 

The provided clinical situation involving a localized abscess and an aspirate displaying filamentous gram-positive bacteria indicates a likelihood of Nocardia infection.

 

  • Nocardia is a gram-positive branching filamentous bacilli.

 

 

  • Modified acid-fast staining: using 1% sulfuric acid as decolorizer (Kinyoun method): Nocardiae are partially acid-fast and appear as branching and filamentous red colored acid-fast bacilli.

 

 

  • Histopathology (H and E stain) of the granules: Shows multilobulated with sun-ray appearance.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Bacillus anthracis, on culture, are arranged end-to-end in long chains → Bamboo-stick appearance.

 

 

Option C. Mycobacterium leprae is an acid-fast, Gram-positive, rod shaped bacterium and an obligate intracellular parasite.

 

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis appear weakly Gram-positive. Acid fast stain is used to identify it.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Nocardia is a gram-positive, branching filamentous bacillus, particularly seen in immunocompromised patients, and can be identified using modified acid-fast staining.

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trombiculid mite

 

The above picture shows the life cycle of trombiculid mite.

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium, is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a vector-borne disease transmitted by infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus

 

The incubation period of scrub typhus is about 6 to 21 days

 

The infection is transmitted to man and rodents by some species of infective trombiculid mites.

 

Once, the mite is infected in nature by feeding on the body fluid of small mammals, including the rodents, they maintain the infection throughout their life stages and, as adults, pass the infection on to their eggs in a process called transovarial transmission. Similarly, the infection passes from the egg to the larva or adult in a process called transstadial transmission. In this way, chigger mite populations can autonomously maintain their infectivity over long periods of time.

 

A large number of the Orientia tsutsugamushi are present in the salivary glands of the larvae and these are injected into its host when it feeds. The bite of the mite leaves a characteristic black eschar that is useful to the doctor for making the diagnosis.

 

Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hard tick: Hard ticks, such as Ixodes species, are vectors for diseases like Lyme disease and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Option B. Soft tick: Soft ticks, like Ornithodoros species, are vectors for diseases such as tick-borne relapsing fever, but are not depicted in the life cycle in the image.

 

Option D. Louse: Lice are vectors for diseases like epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

The trombiculid mite, particularly its larval stage (chigger), is the vector for scrub typhus, transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans and rodents through its bite, which leaves a characteristic black eschar.

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Identify the following organism: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

    
The patient presents with symptoms of urethral discharge and dysuria, along with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse, which strongly suggests a sexually transmitted infection. The image provided shows Gram-negative diplococci, which are characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically causes symptoms like purulent discharge from the urethra, dysuria, and may be accompanied by other complications if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H. ducreyi: This bacterium causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful ulcers on the genitalia, not typically associated with pus discharge and dysuria as seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Candida: While Candida species can cause infections, they usually lead to candidiasis, presenting with symptoms like itching, discharge, and irritation but not the Gram-negative diplococci seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:


Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonorrhea, characterized by urethral discharge and dysuria, especially following unprotected sexual intercourse.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is another helminth with a similar skin-penetrating infection method, but its life cycle is characterized by direct development into adult worms in the intestine after migration, without a free-living phase.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: This helminth has a different life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which then hatch in the intestine, and larvae migrate through the liver and lungs before maturing in the intestine.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Known as pinworm, this helminth has a life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which hatch in the intestine, and the adult worms live in the colon and rectum.

 

Educational Objective:


Strongyloides stercoralis infects through skin penetration by filariform larvae from contaminated soil.

questions.text: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is typically cultured in which medium? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lowenstein-Jensen medium

 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis requires a special medium for growth and cannot grow on routine culture media. Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium is the standard and most commonly used medium for culturing M. tuberculosis. This medium contains:

 

  • Coagulated egg proteins
  • Glycerol
  • Asparagine
  • Potato flour
  • Mineral salts: The medium provides essential nutrients and supports the slow growth of mycobacteria over 3-8 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macconkey agar: Incorrect 

 

  • This medium is used for growing and differentiating Gram-negative enteric bacteria
  • It contains bile salts and crystal violet which inhibit Gram-positive bacteria
  • M. tuberculosis cannot grow on this medium

 

Option C. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Incorrect

 

  • This is a selective medium used for isolating fungi
  • Its acidic pH and high glucose concentration make it unsuitable for bacterial growth
  • M. tuberculosis requires more complex nutrients not present in this medium

 

Option D. Mueller-Hinton agar: Incorrect

 

  • This is a non-selective medium primarily used for antibiotic susceptibility testing
  • It lacks the specific nutrients required for mycobacterial growth
  • The growth time required by M. tuberculosis is too long for this medium

 

Educational Objective: 

 

M. tuberculosis requires specific growth conditions and must be cultured on Lowenstein-Jensen medium, which provides the necessary nutrients for its slow growth over several weeks.

choices.text: It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

questions.text: A patient with HIV develops diarrhea and faecal examination shows Isospora belli. He was treated with cotrimoxazole. Diarrhoea subsided but fever persisted. Bone marrow examination of this patient is shown in the given image below. Which of the following statement is false? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It cannot be grown in sabouraud dextrose agar

 

Based on the clinical picture, an HIV positive patient had infection with Isospora belli which was treated with cotrimoxazole. The bone marrow examination showed narrow based budding yeast cells suggestive of infection with Histoplasma capsulatum

 

  • Histoplasma capsulatum is a thermally dimorphic fungus which exists as a mycelial form at ambient temperatures and grows as small round budding yeast cells at body temperature in mammals.
  • Growth on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 25ºC shows a white to brown colony, cottony mycelium after 2 to 3 weeks.
  • The mold phase is characterized by thin, branching, septate hyphae that produce microconidia and a very distinct spore called a tuberculate macroconidium.
  • Grown at 37ºC shows the budding yeast form. Yeast cells occur within budding yeasts as intracellular fungi.
  • The yeast cell is 2-4 µm in diameter and slightly oval in shape and found exclusively within macrophages.
  • Mode of infection - Inhalation of spores
  • Disseminated infection can occur in immunocompromised patients with reticuloendothelial system being affected the most.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spores are infective form: Correct. Spores of Histoplasma capsulatum are the infective form. They are inhaled into the lungs, where they convert to yeast form and cause infection.

 

Option C. It is intracellular budding yeast: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum is an intracellular budding yeast when it infects the host. It is typically found within macrophages.

 

Option D. It can cause systemic disease: Correct. Histoplasma capsulatum can cause systemic disease, especially in immunocompromised individuals, affecting the reticuloendothelial system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum, a thermally dimorphic fungus, can grow on Sabouraud dextrose agar, produce infective spores, exist as an intracellular budding yeast in humans, and cause systemic disease, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

choices.text: Lyophylised Amphotericin B

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Voriconazole

 

Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It can also be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium.

 

The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole: While effective against Aspergillus species, itraconazole is generally considered less effective than voriconazole for invasive cases due to its variable bioavailability and slower onset of action.

 

Option C. Lyophylised Amphotericin B: Often used as a second-line treatment or in patients who cannot tolerate azole antifungals. It has a broader spectrum but is also associated with more severe side effects, particularly nephrotoxicity.

 

Option D. Posaconazole: This is another alternative, especially for prophylaxis against Aspergillus in high-risk patients, but it is generally used when voriconazole is contraindicated or not tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Voriconazole's effectiveness, broad spectrum of activity, and favorable pharmacokinetic profile make it the first-line treatment for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, offering significant benefits in terms of efficacy and patient outcomes in severe fungal infections.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is represented by the given form of replication? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Influenza virus

 

The given image shows the replication of influenza virus.

 

Stages of replication:

 

Replication of influenza A viruses in the lung epithelium.

 

Binding of haemagglutinin (HA), expressed on the surface of the influenza virion, with sialic acid residues linked to cell surface glycans induces binding and fusion of the virion with the plasma membrane of the target cell.

 

The virus then enters the cell via endocytosis or micropinocytosis and is trafficked to the lysosome where acidification activates the proton selective matrix protein-2 viral channel (M2), inducing membrane fusion and dissociation of the viral ribonucleoprotein (RNP) core, which is then transported to the nucleus where viral RNA replication occurs.

 

Progeny viral RNP cores are generated in the cytosol and, with the viral surface proteins, HA and neuraminidase (NA), and other viral proteins, are concentrated in and near lipid rafts at the plasma membrane.

 

Budding of these plasma membrane regions forms complete viral progeny, which is linked to the plasma membrane by HA/sialic acid interactions.

 

Cleavage of sialic acid residues by neuraminidase releases the viral progeny so they are then free to infect other cells, which can be prevented by NA inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis virus: Hepatitis viruses have different replication mechanisms and do not exhibit the specific stages shown in the image for influenza virus.

 

Option C. HIV: HIV is a retrovirus that integrates its RNA into the host DNA using reverse transcriptase, followed by integration into the host genome, which is not depicted in the given image.

 

Option D. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses have a different replication mechanism involving DNA replication within the nucleus and the formation of nucleocapsids in the nucleus, not shown in the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The replication cycle depicted in the image is characteristic of the influenza virus, involving binding of hemagglutinin (HA) to sialic acid residues, endocytosis, acidification within lysosomes, RNA replication in the nucleus, assembly at the plasma membrane, and release mediated by neuraminidase.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

 

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a cytokine that primarily functions as a chemokine. It plays a crucial role in the immune response by attracting and activating neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation through chemotaxis. This movement of neutrophils to the affected area helps in fighting infections effectively, as they are key cells in the innate immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fever: Fever is primarily induced by cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-alpha, not IL-8. These cytokines act on the hypothalamus to increase body temperature, which is a part of the systemic inflammatory response.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte proliferation: Lymphocyte proliferation is mainly associated with cytokines such as IL-2, which stimulates the growth of T cells. IL-8 does not play a direct role in lymphocyte proliferation.

 

Option D. TH1 activation: TH1 activation is driven by cytokines like IL-12 and IFN-gamma, which promote the differentiation of T-helper cells into the TH1 subtype. IL-8 is not involved in this process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Anaplasma phagocytophilum

questions.text: The inclusion body Rickettsial morula is found in neutrophils during infection caused by? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterium known to cause the disease tick-borne fever (TBF) in domestic ruminants in Ixodes ricinus-infested areas in northern Europe. This organism infects granulocytes, particularly neutrophils, leading to the formation of characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies known as morulae.

 

During an infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum, light microscopy of blood smears taken in the initial fever period can often suffice for diagnosis. When these blood smears are stained with May-Grünwald Giemsa, the organisms appear as blue cytoplasmic inclusions within the neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: This bacterium causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which does not typically involve the formation of morulae in neutrophils. Instead, it causes endothelial cell infection leading to vasculitis.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: The causative agent of Mediterranean spotted fever, also does not typically form morulae in neutrophils. Like R. rickettsii, it primarily infects endothelial cells.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: This bacterium causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) and forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils. This distinguishes it from Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which targets neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes the formation of Rickettsial morulae in neutrophils, whereas Ehrlichia chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes.

 

Mnemonic "GAME": Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis.

choices.text: Aplastic anemia - Patients with hereditary hemolytic anemia

questions.text: The following are parvovirus-related disease-population pairs. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE

 

Non-erosive arthritis is indeed a feature of parvovirus B19 infection, but it is not specifically associated with patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Instead, it can occur in otherwise healthy adults, often presenting as transient joint pain and swelling.

 

Other Options:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection can cause several clinical syndromes depending on the patient's age and immune status:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia is typically seen in patients with hereditary hemolytic anemia, such as sickle cell disease, who develop transient aplastic crises due to parvovirus B19 infection. The virus targets erythroid progenitor cells, leading to a temporary cessation of red blood cell production.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis occurs in pregnant women when the fetus is infected with parvovirus B19. The infection can cause severe fetal anemia, leading to heart failure and generalized edema in the fetus.

 

Option C. Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or "slapped cheek" syndrome, commonly occurs in young children. It presents with a characteristic facial rash followed by a lacy, reticular rash on the trunk and limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text:
The following are parvovirus-related manifestations. Identify the incorrect pair? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia
  2. Polymyalgia rheumatica - young women
  3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women
  4. Erythema infectiosum - infants
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is closely associated with giant cell arteritis in women above 50yrs.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Pure red cell aplasia - chronic hemolytic anemia: Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, particularly in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia. The virus affects erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia in these patients.

 

3. Hydrops fetalis - pregnant women: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe fetal complications, including hydrops fetalis, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe edema in the fetus.

 

4. Erythema infectiosum - infants: Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease, is a common manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection in young children, not just infants. It presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polymyalgia rheumatica is typically seen in women above 50 years old and is not related to parvovirus infection in young women. Parvovirus B19 is more commonly associated with conditions such as erythema infectiosum in children, pure red cell aplasia in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, and hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.

 

Additional Information

 

Parvo virus infection -

 

Common symptoms of parvovirus B19 (B19V) infection include a mild nonspecific prodromal illness that may consist of fever (15-30% of patients), malaise, headache, myalgia, nausea, and rhinorrhea; typically beginning 5-7 days after initial infection

 

A diffuse maculopapular rash can appear 1-4 days later and fades to a lacy erythematous rash, which may be pruritic and may spread gradually toward the distal extremities. Most seropositive patients have no history of this classic biphasic illness. The clinical symptoms widely vary, and the classic "slapped cheek" rash is much more common in young children called as erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease or slapped-cheek disease,

 

 

Alternatively, parvovirus B19 infection may manifest with purpuric rash, erythema multiforme, or pruritus of the soles of the feet. Parvovirus B19 may cause a papular-purpuric "gloves-and-socks" syndrome (PPGSS), which manifests as an erythematous exanthem of the hands and feet with a distinct margin at the wrist and ankle joints.

 

Transient small joint arthropathy may be the main clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 in adults.

 

Pure red cell aplasia and chronic hemolytic anemia is seen  in patients with immunosuppression.

 

Patients with severe anemia due to transient aplastic crisis (TAC) may present with pallor, fatigue, or signs of an aplastic crisis.

 

Parvovirus B19V infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis and/or fetal loss.

questions.text: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zika Virus

 

The image shows transplacental transmission of Zika virus given causing microcephaly.

 

Zika virus crosses the placental barrier and the developing blood–brain barrier (BBB). ZIKV exhibits clear tropism for proliferative neural cells, often with cytotoxic effects. ZIKV also productively and detrimentally infects cranial neural crest cells (CNCC), which give rise to cranial bones and can exert paracrine effects on the developing brain. Once Zika virions enter neurogenic regions in the brain, they reduce the number of mitotic progenitor cells by promoting cell cycle arrest and apoptotic cell death, autophagy, or possibly by precocious differentiation resulting in microcephaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus primarily causes encephalitis and respiratory illness but does not typically cause congenital infections or microcephaly.

 

Option C. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV can cause congenital infections and microcephaly, but the image and description provided are specific to Zika virus.

 

Option D. Rubella: Rubella virus can cause congenital rubella syndrome, which includes microcephaly among other defects, but the specific viral transmission and pathology detailed in the image refer to Zika virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Zika virus is known for causing microcephaly through transplacental transmission by infecting and damaging neural progenitor cells in the developing fetal brain.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA

 

Northern blotting is a laboratory technique used to detect specific RNA sequences within a sample. This method involves the separation of RNA by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labeled complementary DNA probe. The technique allows for the identification and analysis of RNA molecules, making it a valuable tool in gene expression studies and diagnostic applications. The name "Northern blotting" was coined as a play on words, referencing the "Southern blot," a technique used for DNA detection developed by Edward M. Southern.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. DNA: This is detected by Southern blotting, not Northern blotting. Southern blotting involves the identification of specific DNA sequences using DNA probes.

 

Option C. Proteins: This is detected by Western blotting. Western blotting uses antibodies to identify specific protein sequences after separation by SDS-PAGE.

 

Educational Objective

 

SNoW - DRoP:-

 

  1. SOUTHERN - DNA
  2. NORTHERN - RNA
  3. WESTERN - Protein

questions.text: A patient of sickle cell anemia developed aplastic crisis after a viral infection. The agent causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

Parvovirus B19 is known for its predilection for erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, which it infects and destroys. This leads to a transient halt in red blood cell production, which can precipitate an aplastic crisis, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders like sickle cell anemia. The virus effectively shuts down erythropoiesis (red blood cell production), causing a significant drop in hemoglobin levels and resulting in severe anemia.

 

Patients with sickle cell anemia are particularly susceptible to this type of crisis because they already have a high rate of red blood cell turnover due to the intrinsic hemolysis caused by their abnormal hemoglobin. When Parvovirus B19 infection superimposes on this condition, the cessation of red cell production can lead to a profound aplastic crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause various infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it is not known to specifically cause aplastic crises or target red blood cell production.

 

Option B. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV is associated with infectious mononucleosis and can affect the lymphoid tissue but does not directly cause aplastic crisis by targeting red blood cell production.

 

Option C. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): HBV primarily affects the liver, causing hepatitis, and does not have a known mechanism of inducing aplastic crisis by directly affecting the bone marrow's red blood cell production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the primary viral agent responsible for causing aplastic crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia due to its affinity for and destruction of erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.

choices.text: Cell mediated and antibody mediated response

questions.text: Type IV hypersensitivity is due to: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cell mediated response

 

A Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by T cells that provoke an inflammatory reaction against exogenous or endogenous antigens. In certain situations, other cells, such as monocytes, eosinophils, and neutrophils, can be involved. After antigen exposure, an initial local immune and inflammatory response occurs that attracts leukocytes. The antigen engulfed by the macrophages and monocytes is presented to T cells, which then becomes sensitized and activated. These cells then release cytokines and chemokines, which can cause tissue damage and may result in illnesses. It is considered a delayed hypersensitivity reaction because it usually occurs more than 12 hours after exposure to the allergen, with a maximal reaction time between 48 and 72 hours.

 

Examples of illnesses resulting from type IV hypersensitivity reactions include contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell mediated and antibody mediated response: This is not correct for Type IV hypersensitivity, which is exclusively cell-mediated and does not involve antibodies.

 

Option C. Antibody mediated response: This describes Type I, II, and III hypersensitivities, which involve IgE, IgG, or IgM antibodies, respectively. Type IV is exclusively cell-mediated.

 

Option D. Innate response: While the innate immune response involves cells like macrophages and neutrophils, Type IV hypersensitivity specifically involves the adaptive immune system, particularly T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IV hypersensitivity is a cell-mediated response primarily involving T cells and other immune cells, leading to delayed-type reactions such as contact dermatitis and drug hypersensitivity.

 

The four types of hypersensitivity are:

 

  1. Type I: reaction mediated by IgE antibodies
  2. Type II: cytotoxic reaction mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies
  3. Type III: reaction mediated by immune complexes
  4. Type IV: delayed reaction mediated by cellular response

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus multilocularis

 

E. multilocularis leads to alveolar or multilocular hydatid cyst. The liver is the most commonly affected organ. The multilocular infiltrating lesion appears like a grossly invasive growth, without any fluid or free brood capsule or scolices which can be mistaken for a malignant tumor.

 

Patients present with upper quadrant and epigastric pain. Liver enlargement and obstructive jaundice may also be present. It may also metastasize to the spleen, lungs and brain in 2% cases.

 

The prognosis is very grave and if untreated, 70% cases progress to death.

 

Surgical resection, when possible, is the best method of treatment. Albendazole therapy is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery. In those cases, where surgery is not possible, indefinite treatment with albendazole is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Echinococcus granulosus: Causes cystic echinococcosis or hydatid disease, which typically involves the formation of fluid-filled cysts rather than alveolar-like lesions.

 

Option C. Entamoeba histolytica: Causes amoebic liver abscesses, which are different in appearance and pathology from the lesions caused by Echinococcus multilocularis.

 

Option D. Cysticercus cellulose: The larval stage of Taenia solium, which causes cysticercosis. It can form cysts in various tissues but does not cause alveolar-like lesions in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver, leading to a serious condition known as alveolar echinococcosis. The prognosis is poor without treatment, emphasizing the importance of early detection and appropriate therapy.

questions.text: Relapse is seen in? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasmodium viva and ovale

 

Malaria relapse:

 

  • In case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts and others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites.
  • True relapse is caused due to hypnozoites (resting forms). Some get activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In case of Plasmodium falciparum and malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium vivax and falciparum: While P. vivax can cause relapse, P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites and therefore does not cause relapse.

 

Option B. Plasmodium ovale and falciparum: P. ovale can cause relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax and malariae: P. vivax causes relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. malariae does not form hypnozoites and does not cause relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relapse in malaria is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale due to the presence of hypnozoites, the dormant liver stages that can reactivate and cause renewed infection.

questions.text: Identify the organism given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Balantidium coli

 

The given image is the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli.

 

Balantidium coli occurs in two stages

 

  • Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over the entire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end is broad. At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, there is a small anal pore (cytopyge).
  • Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.

 

Living trophozoites/cysts are yellowish or greenish in color on wet mount.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba dispar: Entamoeba dispar is morphologically identical to Entamoeba histolytica but non-pathogenic. It does not have the characteristic cilia and shape seen in Balantidium coli.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium species are small protozoans that cause cryptosporidiosis. They appear as small, round oocysts and do not have cilia.

 

Option D. Giardia: Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan that causes giardiasis. Its trophozoites have a distinctive pear shape with flagella and two nuclei that resemble "eyes."

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balantidium coli is characterized by its oval shape, presence of cilia, and distinct anterior and posterior ends in the trophozoite form. The trophozoite stage contains two nuclei and is motile, while the cyst stage is smaller and round, aiding in transmission and infection.

choices.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
It is an obligate extracellular parasite
Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite

 

The given image shows the amastigote form of leishmaniasis located intracellularly in macrophages. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite.

 

Buffy coat is the portion of blood that contains concentrates of white blood cells, including monocytes and platelets, and for obvious reasons its smear can be examined for detection of L. donovani bodies in suspected VL patients.

 

Detection of Leishmania donovani bodies in peripheral blood buffy coat smears is an alternative and minimally invasive procedure for the parasitological diagnosis of VL.

 

PCR assay with buffy coat preparations to detect Leishmania DNA has been found to be 10 times more sensitive than that with whole-blood preparation.

 

Serodiagnosis is a valid and the detection in serum and urine specimens of antileishmanial antibody against recombinant antigens such as rK39 by rapid immunochromatographic tests

 

Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.

 

Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test

 

Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from nonimmune subjects and endemicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is an obligate extracellular parasite: This is incorrect. Leishmania donovani is an intracellular parasite that resides within macrophages.

 

Option C. It is transmitted from sheep: This is incorrect. Leishmania is transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies, not by sheep.

 

Option D. Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India: This is partially outdated. Sodium stibogluconate was once the first line of treatment, but now liposomal amphotericin B and miltefosine are commonly used as first-line treatments in India due to increased resistance to antimonials.

 

Educational Objective:


Buffy coat is used to diagnose Leishmania donovani by detecting the amastigote form in intracellular macrophages in patients with visceral leishmaniasis.

choices.text: Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid-water

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carbol fuschin - acid-alcohol - methylene blue

 

Clinical history along with microscopic picture is suggestive of mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Microphotograph is of TB bacillus, Mycobacterium tuberculosis on an oil-immersion smear slide stained with Ziehl-Neelsen or acid-fast staining of a clinical sample. Bacilli are long and rod-shaped; a bacillus is indicated by a black arrow. Acid-fast bacilli are bright red after staining.

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique is a differential staining technique that was initially developed by Ziehl and modified later by Neelsen, hence the name Ziehl-Neelsen stain.

 

Reagent used in Ziehl Neelson stain are-

 

  • Carbol-Fuschin (Primary dye)
  • 20% sulphuric acid or acid-alcohol (Decolorizer)
  • Methylene Blue dye (counterstain) or malachite green

 

The use of acid-alcohol in the technique earned it the name Acid-Fast Stain and the application of heat in the technique gives it the name the hot method of Acid-Fast staining

 

Mycobacterium, Nocardia, Isospora, Cryptosporidium, and some fungi contain a thick cell wall made up of lipoidal complexes known as mycolic acid.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gentian violet - iodine - alcohol - safranin: This sequence is used for Gram staining, not for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option B. Methylene blue - malachite green - acetic acid - water: This sequence is not used for any standard bacterial staining protocol.

 

Option C. Methanol - methylene blue - acid - water: This sequence does not correspond to the Ziehl-Neelsen stain or any other standard staining protocol for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ziehl-Neelsen staining method, involving carbol fuschin, acid-alcohol, and methylene blue, is used to identify Mycobacterium tuberculosis in clinical samples. This technique highlights acid-fast bacilli, which retain the red color of carbol fuschin even after decolorization with acid-alcohol.

questions.text: A patient presented with retro-orbital pain and rash since the 5 days. Most appropriate test to be done now is:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody detection by ELISA

 

When diagnosing dengue fever, the timing of the test is crucial. Dengue virus infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus, its RNA, or its antigens, as well as by detecting antibodies against the virus.

 

NS1 Ag ELISA (Option A) and Dengue RNA by PCR (Option B) are methods used to detect the presence of the dengue virus or its antigens in the early stages of the infection, typically within the first 1-5 days of symptom onset. This is because the viral load and antigen levels are highest during this period.

 

Antibody detection by ELISA (Option C) becomes more appropriate after the initial phase of infection, typically after 5-7 days. At this point, the patient's immune system has started producing antibodies (IgM and IgG) against the virus, which can be detected using ELISA.

 

Viral culture (Option D), while definitive, is not typically used in routine clinical practice due to its complexity, cost, and time requirements.

 

Since the patient has been symptomatic for 5 days, it is likely that antibodies have begun to be produced. Therefore, the most appropriate test at this stage is the detection of antibodies by ELISA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS1 Ag ELISA: This test is most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection when the NS1 antigen is present in the blood. After this period, its sensitivity decreases.

 

Option B. Dengue RNA by PCR: This test is also most effective within the first 1-5 days of infection for detecting the viral RNA. After this period, the viral load decreases, making the test less effective.

 

Option D. Viral culture: This method is not commonly used in routine practice due to its complexity and time-consuming nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms for more than 5 days, the most appropriate diagnostic test is antibody detection by ELISA, as antibodies are typically present after 5-7 days of infection.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospira

 

The organisms in the image are leptospira.

 

In spirochetes, the presence of two axial filaments (periplasmic flagella) with polar insertions are located in periplasmic space called as endoflagella, which are responsible for the characteristic corkscrew motion of these bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species are comma-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, commonly known for causing cholera (Vibrio cholerae).

 

Option C. Helicobacter: Helicobacter pylori are spiral-shaped bacteria known for causing stomach ulcers and are Gram-negative.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Salmonella species are rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, known for causing foodborne illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospira is identified by its spiral morphology with axial filaments (endoflagella) and is a type of spirochete, along with Treponema and Borrelia.

 

Endoflagella are seen in:

 

  • Treponema
  • Borrelia
  • Leptospira
